message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the microscopic examination suggest Hodgkin lymphoma. CD15/30 positive cells are seen in Hodgkin lymphoma. Anti-viral capsid antigen IgG and IgM positive would suggest a current or past infection with Epstein-Barr virus, but this is not relevant to the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma. Leukocyte count > 500,000/μL would suggest leukemia, and acid fast bacilli in the sputum would suggest tuberculosis, neither of which is suggested by the patient’s symptoms and physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, history of infectious mononucleosis, and enlarged lymph nodes suggest Hodgkin's lymphoma. CD15/30 positive cells are present in Hodgkin's lymphoma, while options A, C, and D are not associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest lymphoma, which is confirmed by the microscopic examination of the lymph node biopsy. Option B, CD15/30 positive cells, is a common finding in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Options A, C, and D are not associated specifically with lymphoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, enlarged cervical lymph nodes, and biopsy results suggested Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Among the additional findings, only CD15/30 positive cells are suggestive of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. The anti-viral capsid antigen IgG and IgM positive are suggestive of Epstein-Barr virus infection which the patient had in the past. Leukocyte count > 500,000/μL is suggestive of leukemia and Acid fast bacilli in the sputum are suggestive of tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and microscopic examination suggest Hodgkin lymphoma. Among the options, only CD15/30 positive cells are associated with Hodgkin lymphoma. Anti-viral capsid antigen IgG and IgM positive is associated with infectious mononucleosis, but the patient had it 2 years ago. Leukocyte count > 500,000/μL suggests leukemia, not lymphoma. Acid fast bacilli in the sputum suggest tuberculosis, which is not likely present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the biopsy results suggest Hodgkin lymphoma. Among the options, only option B (CD15/30 positive cells) is associated with Hodgkin lymphoma. Option A is associated with Epstein-Barr virus. Option C is associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia. Option D is associated with tuberculosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including recurring fever, night sweats, weight loss, and cervical lymph node enlargement, suggest lymphoma. The provided biopsy result shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which are indicative of Hodgkin lymphoma. CD15 and CD30 are markers for Hodgkin lymphoma cells, so option (B) is the correct choice. Anti-viral capsid antigen IgG and IgM positive would indicate an Epstein-Barr virus infection, which is associated with infectious mononucleosis but not necessarily lymphoma. Leukocyte count > 500,000/μL would indicate leukemia, not lymphoma. Acid fast bacilli in the sputum would indicate tuberculosis, which is not associated with the symptoms or findings in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of fever, night sweats, weight loss, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. The biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma. Among the options, only CD15/30 positive cells are associated with Hodgkin lymphoma. Option A is commonly seen in Epstein-Barr virus infection, which was reported in the patient's medical history. Option C suggests leukemia, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation. Option D suggests tuberculosis, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hodgkin’s lymphoma, which is characterized by enlarged lymph nodes, recurring fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The microscopic examination of the biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Among the options, only CD15/30 positive cells are associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Anti-viral capsid antigen IgG and IgM positive suggest Epstein-Barr virus infection, which may cause infectious mononucleosis but is not relevant to the current symptoms. Leukocyte count > 500,000/μL suggests leukemia, which is not relevant to the current symptoms. Acid fast bacilli in the sputum suggest tuberculosis, which may cause night sweats and weight loss but is not relevant to the current symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lymphoma, and the image shown on the microscopic examination of the lymph node biopsy confirms this diagnosis. Among the options, CD15/30 positive cells are commonly seen in Hodgkin lymphoma. The other options are not associated with this type of lymphoma.
